definition[0]: to be just able to see or hear something
example[0]: He could just make out a dark shape moving towards him.
example[1]: I couldn’t make out what he was saying.
definition[1]: to understand something, especially the reason why something has happened
example[2]: As far as I can make out, he has never been married.
example[3]: I couldn’t make out what I had done to annoy her.
definition[2]: to understand someone’s character and the way they behave
example[4]: Stuart’s a strange guy – I can’t make him out at all.
definition[3]: to write something such as a bill or cheque
example[5]: She was making out a list of people to invite.
example[6]: The book gives advice on making out a will.
example[7]: Make the cheque out to ‘Grays Ltd’.
definition[4]: to say that something is true when it is not
example[8]: The situation was never as bad as the media made out.
example[9]: She always tried to make out that I was wrong and she was right.
example[10]: He makes me out to be some sort of idiot.
note[4]: make somebody/something out to be something
definition[5]: to find good reasons that prove something or show why you need something
example[11]: We made out a case for hiring another assistant.
definition[6]: to succeed or progress in a particular way
example[12]: How did you make out this morning?
definition[7]: to kiss and touch someone in a sexual way
definition[8]: to get or win a lot of money
example[13]: The lawyers made out like bandits.
definition[9]: to write a cheque, bill etc so that it can be paid to someone
example[14]: Can you make the cheque out to me?
example[15]: How did you make out at the interview?
